criteria: Ability to Identify Strategies for Increasing Physical Activity
Knowledge of Methods for Monitoring Physical Activity
Application of Knowledge to Personal Health and Wellness
descriptions: The student demonstrates no understanding of recommended physical activity levels or guidelines.
The student shows a minimal understanding of physical activity recommendations, with significant gaps in knowledge.
The student identifies some physical activity recommendations but struggles to explain them clearly or accurately.
The student accurately describes general physical activity recommendations for their age group.
The student demonstrates a comprehensive understanding of physical activity recommendations, including frequency, intensity, time, and type (FITT).
The student demonstrates an exceptional understanding of physical activity recommendations and can tailor them to specific populations or individual needs.
The student is unable to identify any strategies for increasing physical activity.
The student identifies one or two vague or impractical strategies for increasing physical activity.
The student suggests a few basic strategies for increasing physical activity, but they may not be well-explained or relevant.
The student identifies several practical strategies for increasing physical activity in different settings (e.g., school, home, community).
The student proposes a variety of creative and effective strategies for increasing physical activity, considering individual preferences and barriers.
The student designs a comprehensive and personalized plan for increasing physical activity, incorporating behavior change techniques and addressing potential challenges.
The student is unaware of any methods for monitoring physical activity.
The student mentions one or two basic methods for monitoring physical activity, but lacks understanding of how to use them.
The student identifies a few common methods for monitoring physical activity, such as step counters or activity logs.
The student describes various methods for monitoring physical activity, including wearable devices, apps, and self-assessment tools.
The student explains the benefits and limitations of different methods for monitoring physical activity, and can select appropriate tools based on individual needs and goals.
The student designs a personalized system for monitoring physical activity, incorporating multiple methods and analyzing data to track progress and make adjustments.
The student is unable to connect the concepts of physical activity, monitoring, and personal health.
The student makes a weak attempt to relate physical activity to personal health, but their understanding is superficial.
The student acknowledges the importance of physical activity for health but struggles to apply this knowledge to their own life.
The student explains how increasing and monitoring physical activity can contribute to personal health and well-being.
The student develops a realistic and actionable plan for increasing their own physical activity and monitoring their progress.

The student demonstrates a commitment to lifelong physical activity by consistently monitoring their activity levels, adapting their plan as needed, and advocating for physical activity in their community.
